nodes.text: Policymaking should report both ensemble-average (GDP per capita) and time-average (DDP per capita) growth rates because when incomes follow random multiplicative growth the ensemble-average exceeds the time-average, creating an ergodicity gap (MLD) that signals rising inequality and can cause political disconnect
Ergodicity economics distinguishes ensemble averages and time averages: if a stochastic process is ergodic they coincide, otherwise they can differ with policy-relevant implications
Under random multiplicative growth (Gibrat-type processes), the ensemble-average growth rate of income is greater than the time-average growth rate realized by individual trajectories

Definitions and constructs: ensemble-average growth rate = growth of average income (GDP per capita); time-average growth rate = long-run individual growth (DDP per capita); DDP per capita equals the geometric mean exp(mean(log incomes)) and time-average growth can be estimated from initial and terminal distributions

The difference between ensemble-average and time-average growth rates defines the ergodicity gap J(t) = ln(mean income) - mean(ln incomes), which equals the mean logarithmic deviation (MLD) and serves as a measure of income inequality
Analytical example (geometric Brownian motion): ensemble-average growth rate g_ensemble = mu, time-average growth rate g_time = mu - sigma^2/2, showing ensemble > time by sigma^2/2
In GBM the ergodicity gap grows linearly in time: dJ/dt = sigma^2/2 so J(t) = (sigma^2/2) t (up to constant), implying unbounded increase of MLD under pure multiplicative noise
The ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth rate is a plutocratic measure: approximately an income-weighted average of individual growth rates (weights proportional to income)

The time-average (DDP per capita) growth rate is a democratic measure: the average of individual growth rates with equal weight, and it is independent of income mobility because it depends only on initial and terminal log-income distributions

Empirical method: estimate g_ensemble from national average income and g_time (DDP) from quantile data using mean(log incomes) approximated by quantile averages; truncation of low incomes can affect geometric mean estimates, so bottom decile was excluded in primary figures

Evidence from US data (1966-2014): between 1966 and 1980 ensemble and time-average growth were similar, but since 1980 ensemble-average (GDP per capita) grew ~+40% while time-average (DDP) grew ~+20%, indicating widening ergodicity gap

Evidence from France data (1970-2015): ensemble-average and time-average growth rates remained close and ergodicity gap roughly stable, so GDP per capita was more representative of typical experience than in the US

Policy conclusion: reporting both GDP per capita (ensemble-average) and DDP per capita (time-average) together with the ergodicity gap (MLD) would better inform policymakers about total productive capacity and typical individual experience

Societal implication claim: persistent divergence (ensemble > time) can produce increasing inequality, create a political disconnect where official statistics show prosperity not felt by typical citizens, and may erode trust in institutions

Limitations and assumptions: main results rely on multiplicative random-growth null model without interactions or redistribution; real economies may include reallocation, correlations, and measurement issues (sensitivity of geometric mean to low incomes and need for truncation)
